Hi guys! My name is Anton. I'm a JavaScript developer at Dash. As you may know, we are using your bls library in Dash. We also support BitPay's JS stack, which means that we have javascript wallet libraries. So I've ported your bls-signatures library to JavaScript. 

https://github.com/Chia-Network/bls-signatures/pull/55

I also own https://www.npmjs.com/package/bls-signatures npm package, which I can give to you in case if you want.

edit.body: I agree the abstraction would make swapping curves much easier

text.body: I agree the abstraction would make swapping curves much easier
I would start with the basic signature and verification and try to get it working, then basic aggregates, etc

The largest changes to relic are the following:
ep_nao and ep_2 map were rewritten with a new algorithm
eo_pck and ep2_pck were rewritten
A custom inversion function used for signature division

I don't think any of these changes were required for swapping curves. Relic actually has a simple signature and verification of BLS using the opposite curves, which is here: https://github.com/Chia-Network/bls-signatures/blob/master/contrib/relic/src/cp/relic_cp_bls.c
I spent a week diffing code and tracing what happens in gdb, but unfortunately have hit a dead end.
Any changes @sorgente711 made to relic related to swapping g1/g2 could certainly be relevant. I'm happy to document further my testing too or follow up any leads people suggest.
I put his into a test branch to play with it, but I agree I would need to abstract it to be useful.
And the issues you have might be related to these changes actually
Also, there were some changes in relic as well that @sorgente711 implemented to make the swapping work, you might need to abstract these changes as well

I need to leave it for a while and work on other things, but would like to figure this out at some point. I'm sure it's just some more complicated change beyond swapping g1/g2 that I'm missing.
FYI, I've checked in a branch in my local repository with my changes. https://github.com/remyers/bls-signatures/commit/2b1641e26aa03e0fd48e8f658011a59af284ab0b

text.body: Does the BLS Lib compile on Windows without any... special tricks?
Our VDF competition is up: https://github.com/Chia-Network/vdf-competition
A SNARG is like a SNARK but is used for the compression feature rather than the zero knowledge feature
SNARG?
Also computers are likely to have more cores, and it may be possible to add a SNARG of signature validity
I believe Bitcoin only checks the last two years of signatures for validity, although it does do the weight calculations, because those are so cheap
So...doesn't look "that bad" :D

I assume that you're going to implement optimizations like in Bitcoin which skip verification of blocks below a known "good block" (which is updated with every release), so only a few weeks/months would have to be fully validated.

Some calculations based on 20tx/s:
20tx per second
*60 = 1200 per minute
*60 = 72000 per hour
*24 = 1728000 per day

Batch verification takes around 1ms per distinct message. As every TX is a distinct message, we have 1728000 verifications for a full day worth of blocks, which means a full day worth of TXs takes 1728 seconds or 28 minutes to verify.

Let's assume we are multithreaded with 4 cores, so it's 7 minutes for a day's TXs. Syncing a week would take 49 minutes, a month would be 196 minutes, a year would be 39 hours. After 5 years it would already take 8 days to do a full sync.
There will be a single aggregate signature per block
My notes are that we wish to target 20 simple transactions per second
Or better question: Which throughput (TX/s) are you targetting. Block size is hard to compare as BLS aggregation results in more TXs per MB
Doing some calculations atm. Do you already know how large blocks will be?
@codablock Mostly we take the hit. The big performance problems with initial synch have to do with blowing memory and having to do a zillion disk seeks, which are a different sort of problem to fix

I'm wondering...as Chia plans to exclusively use BLS for transactional signing/verification, how do you plan to solve performance issues with initial sync? I understand that the performance of BLS is acceptable when it comes to transactions which come in while the local chain is up-to-date, but when doing the initial sync this is a different beast. Blocks come in with thousands of transactions which need to be verified as fast as possible, while no optimizations like signature division can be used at that time.

How do you plan to speed this up?

edit.body: Thanks for the info. My current setup has everyone publishing individual signatures and the miners publishing the aggregate so I'll be fine.

text.body: Thanks for the info. My current setup has everyone publishing individual signatures and the miners publishing the aggregate so I'll be fine.

Also you always have the option to aggregating everything in one straight shots. It's just when you're stuck aggregating aggregates that that feature matters. Like when you're making a block out of transactions, for example

@techaspirer The point is that you have to remember how you aggregate them and do it the same way when you validate or it might not work. If all the messages you're aggregating are guaranteed to be different then it doesn't matter though
NVM on the above. I was asking to be careful but my code says I'm good.

edit.body: Why do the BLS examples in the README aggregate sig1 + sig2 via a vector but then sig12 + sig3? Is it to show the order/timing doesn't matter and it all ends up in the same place or is there a reason to only aggregate 2 at a time? The function implementations iterate over every item in the vector via `:`, so it seems they do not care...

text.body: Why do the BLS examples in the README aggregate sig1 + sig2 via a vector but then sig12 + sig3? Is it to show the order/timing doesn't matter and it all ends up in the same place or is there a reason to only aggregate 2 at a time? The function implementations iterate over every item in the vector via `:`, so it seems they do not care...
Sure
Constant time is our lowest priority task for BLS. Our first order of business is to get the format settled on and evaluated because that's the consensus critical thing
Seems like a fair answer.
Harry is a guy with blue hair who lives in San Francisco
It's not like I have a mass pool of funds to offer myself anyways.
And sure. Sorry if I'm pressuring you in any way. Just excited to use BLS and I want to make sure the schedules work out.
Who's Harry? :P
Apparently the way to get a constant time implementation is to pay Harry to do it
We mostly have scaling up staffing issues and lots of stuff to work on. Also some things take time no matter what, like publication and getting an audit
I mean, of course a billion dollars (if used right) would make any program get completed faster...

Sounds great. It looks from your website you do have capital. Mind if I ask if it's a "We have capital but it's stretched thin" or "We have capital and more money wouldn't make us work faster" situation?
Let's say 3-6 months for security audit and constant time. Hopefully. Depending on other stuff.
Sure

For us getting confident that we're done messing with the construction and getting it published are the first priority, because we don't want to have to redo the other things after tweaking for security reasons

I'm working on a project that can really benefit from BLS and you have the best lib out there. If you were guessing what we're closest to, are we talking 1 month, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months, or longer?
@bramcohen Thanks for the info. The two things you mentioned (constant time + audit) are the things I'm considering.
@jonspock At the moment our level of diff from Relic is fairly small so we aren't sweating it too much. Still maintaining though so we'll see where we land.

@techaspirer No concrete plans at this time but we fully intend to publish the construction in a refereed journal, do a constant time implementation, and get a real security audit. Maybe also add a partridge in a pear tree.

Anyways. Hello, everyone. I'm working on a project and was interested in using Chia's BLS library. i had some questions about it, mainly when the library is predicted to undergo 'audits' and be labelled secure/production ready. I perfectly understand if there's no answer to that yet.

edit.body: Oh, the slowdown might be because relic is storing field elements in montgomery representation and has to convert every time you serialize

text.body: Oh, the slowdown might be because relic is storing field elements in montgomery representation and has to convert every time you serialize
We could do lazy compression, i'm interested in what kind of gains that would lead to. Also every time a public key is copied (copy constructor) point compression happens

edit.body: Well the serialized data is just the x value, with the first bit indicating which y value is used. It should be really fast to convert and x,y to the serialized version. I like sorting by serialized values, as it allows us to sort aggregationInfos by bytes(messageHash + publicKey)

text.body: Well the serialized data is just the x value, with the first bit indicating which y value is used. It should be really fast to convert and x,y to the serialized version. I like sorting by serialized values, as it allows us to sort aggregationInfos by bytes(messageHash + publicKey)
Alternative would be to perform lazy-compression at the time when the serialized data is first needed
This would completely remove the need for pre-compressing points, making it only necessary when Serialize is called
An alternative would be to sort by p->x and p->y on the normalized points

@sorgente711 Is the sorting of public keys by the serialized data mandatory? While profiling my benchmarks, it turned out that keeping track of "data" and thus compression of points takes quite a lot of time when keys and signatures are copied around (which I rely on as I paralellize a lot)
